title.narrative: Provision of life-saving quality education services, school WASH facilities, and child protection emergency services in schools to the most vulnerable, crisis-affected girls and boys, including those with disabilities, in six counties of South Sudan.

description.narrative:
To encourage girls and boys to return to school, UNICEF are improving safe, physical learning environments by establishing 24 temporary learning spaces (84 classrooms) and rehabilitating 24 damaged classrooms. In 58 schools and temporary learning spaces (TLS) without safe water supply, safe water is provided through drilling 30 new water points with hand pumps, converting five boreholes to mechanized water points and rehabilitating 28 hand pumps. This activity will indirectly improve access to safe water for surrounding communities for an estimated 29,000 people. UNICEF is installing gender-separated sanitation and hygiene facilities within schools, also constructed to be accessible for persons with disabilities. These facilities enable children to learn in schools free of open defecation, practice safe hygiene and enabling girls to learn in an environment where they can manage their menses with dignity.
Ensuring schools are equipped with appropriate and quality education materials is essential for positive education outcomes, and to encourage a return to school as well as student retention. UNICEF provide target schools and students with learning materials, including 500 student learning kits, 500 teaching kits, 160 early child development kits and 450 blackboards to enable and improve learning for 27,206 students. The project also mobilizes communities and parents to increase enrollment and facilitate child attendance in schools through 12 ‘back to learning’ campaigns and by promoting girls’ education. The use of diverse mobilization and communication techniques will reach more than 6,000 community members, especially targeting parents of girls and children with disabilities.
The targeted areas report the highest incidents of child rights violations and child protection incidents in the country. Children continue to be exposed to violence, abuse, neglect, and exploitation which often takes the form of family separation, abduction, psychosocial distress, sexual violence, as well as killing and maiming from conflict and unexploded ordnance among other protection concerns. As such, UNICEF integrate child protection into education to ensure that children are protected and are able to learn and thrive in safe and conducive environments. This engagement targets 18,700 children, including those with disabilities (11,200 girls, 7,500 boys) within schools to access mental and psychosocial health services through enhancing teachers’ abilities to provide psychosocial first aid as well as through recreational activities. Girls and boys will also benefit from case management services, including through referral mechanisms to access protective and response services. Additionally, through a child-to-child (peer-to-peer) approach, UNICEF and partners are equipping students and teachers with knowledge on unexploded ordnance and explosive remnants of war, on how to report them and how to protect themselves.
